Award.AwardTitle: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Woody Cover in a Savanna Landscape

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Savanna ecosystems cover vast areas of the earth's land surface and play a key role in biogeochemical cycling by providing habitat for wildlife and resources for rural communities. Empirical evidence and modeling efforts suggest that many of these grass-dominated ecosystems are becoming woodier over time and that these changes will have profound effects on a wide range of ecological and socio-ecological processes of their regions. This research project will analyze the ecological mechanisms and spatial interactions that underpin the process of woody cover change in grassland and savanna systems over the past two decades. The project will provide new perspectives about the impacts that changes in these ecosystems will have in altering their functions including soil moisture dynamics, radiation, soil temperature and nutrients, and carbon cycling and storage. The insights from this project will advance basic understanding about the fundamental forces driving woody cover change across a wide range of environmental settings. Project results will help guide policy makers, governmental agencies, and resource administrators in assessing appropriate courses of action. This project also will strengthen international research collaborations among U.S. and African scientists and institutions.

Interactions between grassland and woody vegetation in a savanna ecosystem depend on the spatial context where even a small change at a fine-scale may have large-scale landscape-level ramifications of modifying entire vegetation distribution patterns. Using remote sensing methods, fieldwork, and spatial modeling, the investigators will seek answers to three core sets of questions: (1) What role do spatial processes play in determining woody cover dynamics at neighborhood scales? (2) Are these spatial processes resource- or disturbance-driven, and do they shift across climate gradients? (3) Do woody cover changes exhibit gradual or abrupt transitions (regime shifts) over time, and how are these dynamics related to fine-scale spatial structure and resource and disturbance gradients? Project findings will lead to a better understanding of the impacts that widespread increases in woody cover are having on habitat structure for wildlife, ecosystem function, and economic activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Globally, savannas are widespread and important ecosystems: they cover 34.4 million km2 (~26.5%) of the earth?s land surface, support a large fraction of rangeland and livestock, and are home to a significant proportion of the human population, notably in sub-Saharan Africa. Savannas are increasing threatened by land degradation, conversion to agriculture and global climate change. Consequently, savannas are crucial human resources which must be effectively managed in the face of these threats in order to ensure their persistence and stability.

Nearly everywhere they occur, savannas are experiencing increased woody plant cover and a loss of grass dominance which defines the savanna state. There is disagreement about what drives savannas from a natural, grass-dominated system to one that is degraded by woody plant cover. A critical step in predicting and mitigating the degradation of savannas and rangelands is to understand the natural processes that create and maintain a healthy savanna. Our project, which is exploring the mechanisms that contribute to the generation and maintenance of the savanna state, will advance the understanding of the dynamics of tropical savannas and thereby providing a strong scientific basis for their management.

To date, models of tree-grass interactions in savannas have largely focused on how stochastic disturbances, primarily herbivory and fire, alter the growth and microsite conditions for tree seedlings in space and time. Except for early work in the field, spatial heterogeneity in soil conditions have largely been ignored when trying to understand patterns of tree seedling recruitment. Our results highlight the important influence that spatial heterogeneity in underlying soil properties have in determining tree-grass dynamics in savannas. We found that soil properties constrain the area in which trees can recruit based on the hydrological demands of woody relative to herbaceous species.

A significant product of our work was a time-series of woody cover change in Serengeti between 2000-2018 produced from satellite data and validated with ground measurements. The time-series maps show strong inter-annual variation in tree cover that lacks a strong threshold effect in tree cover change. It is likely that the lack of rapid, threshold changes in woody cover are caused by the strong constraints of soils we identified in parallel work.

Another significant finding of our study is the dependencies among soil moisture, vegetation and herbivores. We found that soil moisture controls grass growth and nutritional quality (i.e., greenness) in ways that directly influence herbivore site use. However, our results also demonstrated that herbivore use of grassland sites keeps them in a green, growing vegetative state suggestive of a feedback between grasses and herbivores: green grasses attract grazing herbivores and grazing herbivores maintain a green, nutritious grassland state.

At smaller spatial scales we found compelling evidence that grass biomass influences the spatial distribution of tree seedling establishment and success. Sites with greater grass biomass showed greater spatial clustering in the locations of seedlings and ultimately limits woody plant establishment. This novel finding provides important insight into recruitment limitation within savanna ecosystems and provides a tool for reducing encroachment in managed savanna ecosystems.

Our project produced several key pieces of physical and intellectual infrastructure that will inform future science and management of savanna ecosystems. First, we installed a network of climate monitoring stations known as the Serengeti Observatory Network. These data are filling a critical gap in the collection of environmental data in one of the most renowned ecosystems on the planet and will continue to play this role past the funding period of this grant. The service provided by the network is recognized by many of the stakeholders, particularly other scientists who are interested in using the data for ancillary purposes in other analyses. Our weather station data also serve as a critical validation data for continental products that predict rainfall and drought across Africa. A manuscript, currently in preparation, will make the data from the Serengeti Observation Network publicly available. In addition, we produced a series of validated GIS layers (such as fire and vegetation greenness) produced with MODIS satellite data that will serve as important tools for the management of Serengeti and other similar savanna ecosystems. The layers are publicly available as rasters at a spatial resolution of 250 m and available annually between 2000 and 2018. We also developed an R package that is publicly available and disseminates a method for measuring the plant characteristics using spectral data (i.e., near-infrared reflectance data). The package contains a publicly available spectral calibration dataset including plant spectral readings from a network of globally distributed sites.
